moves.3... Bb7 4. Nbd2 Nf6 5. e3: Here, as black, I would have gone for my dsb with Nh5.
moves.5... c5 6. c3: This scheme provides me with nice settings, much less "attacheable" than c4 ones.
moves.6... Nc6 7. h3: I've seen my opponen is not fond with the Nh5 idea, but this is not to provide my bishop of a square to hide as to prepare a pawn storm.
moves.7... Be7 8. g4 O-O: Thank you, just where I wanted you to be.
moves.9. Rg1: This is to unpin the f3 knight and to prepare h4.
moves.9... cxd4 10. exd4: My queenside keeps closed. It is supposed to be the shield for my king, after o-o-o.
moves.12... Bxh4: He falls in it. This just helps me, opening the h column.
moves.13. Bd6: ...but this move was too juicy to delay.
moves.14. g5: He cannot save the bishop, but my king is becoming very exposed, and castling appears very far.
moves.15. Qb1: It was important for me to keep the queen active, and I needed it looking to h7.
moves.15... Nxf1 16. Kxf1: Not with the rook, and not with the knight, because of Nf3 needs protection. This also keeps my king out of the Re8's action (as black, I would have played e5, probably).
moves.16... Ba6+: I considered to shield with c4, but I didn't like b5.
moves.17. Ke1: Well, back to the e column. I thought that now e5 was almost the only black chance.
moves.17... Bxf2+ 18. Kxf2: Well, THIS is an exposed king. I am lucky the Bd6 is untouchable, and cramps him a lot.
moves.18... f6: No, the f column should not be opened!
moves.19. Rh1 g6: I thought Rxh7, and if KxR, Qh1+, followed by Qh6. But I wasn't sure it was enough.
moves.20. Ne4: Bringing more firepower to the enemy's field.
moves.20... fxg5 21. Nexg5: He can now attack the f column, but without much effect.
moves.21... Re7: Intelligent. Returning the exchange in order to free his position. Now I have to be very "osé", if I want to keep my attack.
moves.22. Nxh7: The Nf6+ threat is very dangerous for black. His best answer is Rg7, IMO.
moves.22... Rxh7: But he went greedy, and this is almost mortal. I could have gone RxR, KxR, Qh1+, but after Kg7 I couldn't see a clear win.
moves.23. Qxg6+: My queen returns! ...at the cost of a piece, but the presence of the First Lady into the king whorts it.
moves.24... Qe8 25. Qh8+ Kf7: Again, I have to play very strong to make my attack successful.
moves.26. Ng5+: The nice one. Tempo is all in chess.
moves.26... Rxg5 27. Rh7+ Kg6: I was in doubt if to follow with the queen or the rook. Now, with more time, I realize that Rh6+, Kf5 (Kf7, Qf6+, Kg8, Rh8#), Qf6+, Kg4, Rg1#, but on the spot I didn't. Pity.
moves.28. Rg7+ Kf5: Kf6, Rg8+ and I win. Now, I had to bring in the other rook, and get rid of defensive forces, so...
moves.30. Rg1+: It is funny how long my queen keeps "en prise" undisturbed.-
